name: fs-base
doc:
Low-level file system API.

An implementation of the CommonJS specification,
[http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Filesystem/A/0](http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Filesystem/A/0).

children.name: UNIX_BITS
children.doc:
[
        ['owner', 'read'],
        ['owner', 'write'],
        ['owner', 'execute'],
        ['group', 'read'],
        ['group', 'write'],
        ['group', 'execute'],
        ['other', 'read'],
        ['other', 'write'],
        ['other', 'execute'],
        ['setUid', undefined],
        ['setGid', undefined],
        ['sticky', undefined],
    ]

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: UNIX_BITS_REVERSED
children.doc:
`UNIX_BITS` in reverse order, from most significant to
least significant.

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: Permissions
children.doc: Constructs a permissions object.

children.name: update

params.name: permissions
params.doc: bitwise UNIX permissions as a number, or a permissions object.  The permissions will be deeply updated into this permissions object.

children.doc:
Updates this permissions object with the permissions
from another permissions object.

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: grant
children.doc:
Adds a permission this permissions object.

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: deny
children.doc:
Removes a permission form this permissions object.

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: can

returns.doc: whether this permissions object has the given permission.

children.doc: WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: toUnix

returns.doc: a UNIX bit flag representing this set of permissions.

children.doc: WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: default
children.doc:
The default permissions, as constructed on Unix from the
inverse of `umask`.  This is a property of the the `Permissions`
object proper and can be both gotten as a `Permissions` object
or set with either a `Number` or a `Permissions` object.

from another permissions object.

or set with either a `Number` or a `Permissions` object.

children.name: openRaw

returns.doc: a raw byte stream

children.doc:
Open a file as a raw byte stream.

The following combinations of true `read`, `write`, `update` *
and `append` properties are supported:

* `read`: read only
* `write`: write only, truncates, creates if necessary
* `append`: write only, append, creates if necessary
* `read` and `update`: read and write, does not create, does not
  truncate
* `write` and `update`: read and write, trancates, creates if
  necessary
* `append` and `update`: read and write, does not truncate,
  creates if necessary

On some varieties of UNIX, "append" causes all writes to be
appended, regardless of the seek position.

The following additional properties can be set on the
options and are used when the underlying system supports
them:

* `exclusive`: prevents the file from being opened if it
  a file already exists. Atomicity of the `exclusive` open
  can be used to coordinate processes like daemons.
* `truncate`: explicitly requests truncation of the file
  upon successful open.
* `create`: explicitly requests creation if the file
  does not exist.

The following properties can also be specified but are
not mentioned in the CommonJS standard:

* `xSync`: requests that data be written to disk immediately.
* `xNarwhalNoControlTty`: requests that, if the opened file is
  a terminal device or pseudo terminal, that the calling
  process does not become the controller for that terminal.
* `xNarwhalNoFollow`: ensures that symbolic links are not followed,
  which prevents certain kinds of attacks that take
  advantage of race conditions in opening files where the
  attacker subverts a write by injecting a symbolic link
  at a path that is known to be opened by a process with
  authority in excess of its own.
* `xNarwhalDirectory`

children.name: move
children.doc:
Move the file or directory `source` to `target` using the
underlying OS semantics including atomicity and moving files into
a target directory if the target is a directory (as opposed to
replacing it).

children.name: remove

params.name: path
params.doc: path to a file (not a directory).

children.doc:
Attempt to remove the `file` from disk. To remove
directories use {@link fs-base.removeDirectory}.

children.name: touch
children.doc:
'touch' the path, setting the last modified date to
`mtime` or now. If there is no file or directory at
`path`, an empty file will be created.

children.name: makeDirectory
children.doc:
Creates a (single) directory. If parent directories do
not exist they will not be created by this method.

children.name: removeDirectory
children.doc:
Removes an empty directory. A symbolic link is itself
removed, rather than the directory it resolves to being
removed.

children.name: canonical
children.doc:
Resolve symlinks and canonicalize `path`. If it is a
directory, the returned string will be guarenteed to have
a trailing '/'

children.name: workingDirectory
children.doc: Get the process's current working directory.

children.name: changeWorkingDirectory
children.doc: Change the process's current working directory.

children.name: owner

throws.doc: if the file does not exist

returns.doc: owner the identifier of the owner of a file.

children.doc:
Returns the user identifier of the owner of 
the referenced file.

children.name: group

throws.doc: if the file does not exist.

returns.doc: group the identifier of the group that owns the file.

children.doc:
Returns the group identifier for the group that owns
the referenced file.

children.name: changeOwner

params.name: owner
params.doc: an identifier for the owner of a file

children.doc:
Changes the owner for a referenced file.

WARNING: beyond specification

children.name: changeGroup
children.doc: Sets the group ownership of the given file or directory.

children.name: permissions

returns.doc: a representation of the permissions granted to various users for the given file.

children.doc:
Returns a representation of the permissions granted to
various users for the given file.

children.name: changePermissions
children.doc: Sets the permissions for the given file.

children.name: symbolicLink
children.doc:
Creates a symbolic link at the source path that references
the target path, resolved from the source.

children.name: hardLink
children.doc:
Creates a hard link at the source location that shares
the underlying storage at the target location, effectively
functioning as a copy of the target file, although changes
to one file are immediately reflected in the other.

children.name: readLink

returns.doc: path

children.doc:
Reads the content of a symbolic link at the given path.

See: [http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/000095399/functions/readlink.html](POSIX readlink function)

children.name: exists

returns.doc: whether a file (of any kind, including directories) exists at the given path

children.doc: Returns whether a file exists at the given path.

children.name: isFile

returns.doc: whether a regular file exists at the given path.

children.doc: Returns whether a regular file exists at the given path.

children.name: isDirectory

returns.doc: whether a directory exists at the given path.

children.doc: Returns whether a directory exists at the given path.

children.name: isLink

returns.doc: whether a symbolic link exists at the given path.

children.doc: Returns whether a symbolic link exists at the given path.

children.name: isBlockDevice

returns.doc: whether a block device exists at the given path.

children.doc:
/!\ Warning: beyond specification. Not necessarily
interoperable.

returns.doc: whether a character streaming device exists at the given path.

children.doc:
/!\ Warning: beyond specification. Not necessarily
interoperable.

children.name: isFifo

returns.doc: whether a named pipe device exists at the given path.

children.doc:
/!\ Warning: beyond specification. Not necessarily

children.name: isSocket

returns.doc: whether a UNIX domain socket exists at the given path.

children.doc:
/!\ Warning: beyond specification. Not necessarily
interoperable.

children.name: isReadable

returns.doc: whether `path` is readable.

children.doc:
Warning: this function provides information about the
process owner's rights for information and display
purposes only. The only reliable way to detect whether
a file is writable or readable, without race coditions,
is to attempt to open the file.

children.name: isWritable

returns.doc: whether `path` is writable.

children.doc:
/!\ Warning: this function provides information about the
process owner's rights for information and display
purposes only. The only reliable way to detect whether a
file is writable or readable, without race coditions, is
to attempt to open the file.

children.name: same

returns.doc: whether the paths refer to the same physical storage.

children.doc: Returns whether the paths refer to the same physical storage.

children.name: sameFilesystem

returns.doc: whether the paths are on the same file system.

children.doc: Returns whether the paths are on the same file system.

children.name: size
children.doc:
Return the size of the file in bytes. Due to the way that
ECMAScript behaves, if the file is larger than 65,536,
terabytes accuracy will be lost.

children.name: lastModified

returns.doc: the last modification time of the `path`

children.doc: Returns the last modification time of the `path`

children.name: list

returns.doc: an array of the names of the files in a given directory.

children.doc:
Returns a list of the entries in a directory.  These are
not fully qualified paths, but single directory entry
names.  The self (`'.'`) and parent (`'..'`) directory
entries will not be returned.

children.name: iterate

returns.doc: a directory entry name iterator.

children.doc: Creates a directory iterator.

children.name: next

throws.doc: if there are no further entries.

returns.doc: the next entry name in the directory

children.doc: Returns the next entry name in the directory

children.name: iterate

returns.doc: this iterator

children.doc:
Returns an iterator, itself, so caling iterate
is idempotent.

children.name: close
children.doc: Closes the iteration.

next.name: next

throws.doc: if there are no further entries.

returns.doc: the next entry name in the directory

next.doc: Returns the next entry name in the directory

iterate.name: iterate

returns.doc: this iterator

iterate.doc:
Returns an iterator, itself, so caling iterate
is idempotent.

returns.doc: a raw byte stream

openRaw.doc:
Open a file as a raw byte stream.

The following combinations of true `read`, `write`, `update` *
and `append` properties are supported:

* `read`: read only

* `append`: write only, append, creates if necessary

* `write` and `update`: read and write, trancates, creates if
  necessary
* `append` and `update`: read and write, does not truncate,
  creates if necessary

On some varieties of UNIX, "append" causes all writes to be
appended, regardless of the seek position.

them:

* `exclusive`: prevents the file from being opened if it

* `create`: explicitly requests creation if the file

The following properties can also be specified but are

* `xSync`: requests that data be written to disk immediately.
